questions.question:
Question 1: The peripheral blood smear of a patient is given below. All of the following can cause this 
except:
questions.explanation:
The given image shows hypersegmented neutrophils (> 5 nuclear lobes), which are seen 
in megaloblastic anemia. Chronic alcoholism causes non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia is a form of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism and 
defective erythropoiesis. The causes include vitamin B12 deficiency, folate deficiency, and orotic 
aciduria. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation giving the appearance of 
hypersegmented neutrophils. Peripheral smear findings include: • Oval macrocytes 1300 
Sold by @itachibot • Anisocytosis • Hypersegmented neutrophils Other features of ineffective erythropoiesis seen in megaloblastic anemias include: • Howell-Jolly bodies are nuclear remnants in red cells. They are usually single, round, dark 
purple-red in color and peripheral in location, as shown below. • Basophilic stippling refers to blue granules of various sizes dispersed throughout the cytoplasm 
of the red cell. They represent ribosomal precipitates. • Cabot rings are red cell inclusions appearing as fine, purple filamentous loops or figure-of-eight 
forms, as shown below. They are presumed to be remnants of mitotic spindles.

questions.question: Question 2: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop cobalamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
1301 
Sold by @itachibot Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) infection does not affect the absorption of cobalamin or 
vitamin B12. Small amounts of blood loss during the attachment of hookworms to the intestinal 
mucosa can cause iron-deficiency anemia. Vitamin B12-intrinsic factor (IF) complex is absorbed in the ileum. Tropical sprue, 
Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) infection and Crohn's disease affect the ileum leading to 
defective absorption of vitamin B12.

Sold by @itachibot Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with cyanocobalamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:

conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis. This leads 
to the formation of nucleated RBCs in the marrow, which undergo early lysis. This leads to 
increased unconjugated bilirubin in the plasma. The clinical features of cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency include: System

questions.question:
Question 4: A 56-year-old male patient is being evaluated for peripheral neuropathy and excessive 
tiredness. He has uncontrolled diabetes and consumes alcohol nearly every day. Lab 
investigations reveal the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of folate deficiency. 1302 
Sold by @itachibot It is associated with the following clinical and laboratory findings: • Raised MCV (normal: 80-100 fL) - macrocytosis • Normal MCHC (normal: 33-36 g/dl) • Increased MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) • Elevated RDW (red cell distribution width) • Decreased reticulocyte count - due to destruction of abnormal erythroid precursors • Elevated homocysteine • Normal MMA (methyl malonic acid) In vitamin B12 deficiency, elevated homocysteine and elevated MMA levels are seen. Peripheral neuropathy is a feature of B12 deficiency, not folate deficiency. In this patient, it may 
be due to diabetic neuropathy.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following drugs is not associated with megaloblastic anemia?
questions.explanation:
Temafloxacin is not associated with megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia is associated with the following drugs: • Anticonvulsant drugs - phenytoin, primidone, barbiturates • Sulfasalazine • Nitrofurantoin • Tetracycline • Folate antagonists - trimethoprim, methotrexate, pyrimethamine, pentamidine, cotrimoxazole Temafloxacin is a fluoroquinolone with severe adverse effects like hemolytic anemia and allergic 
reactions. It was withdrawn from the market and is no longer used.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 45-year-old woman is rushed to the ER following a seizure. She is a known case of epilepsy 
but is non-compliant with her medications. Her lab values are given below. All of the 
following drugs can cause this presentation except:
questions.explanation:
This patient likely has folate deficiency secondary to the use of an anti-folate anti-convulsant 
drug. Lamotrigine has no effect on folate metabolism and does not cause its deficiency. The following anticonvulsants have anti-folate properties: • Phenytoin • Barbiturates (amobarbital) • Primidone Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic macrocytic anemia which results in the following findings 
in RBCs: • Anemia (low Hb = 10g/dl) 1303 
Sold by @itachibot • Macrocytic (high MCV = 110 fl) • Hyperchromic (high MCH = 40 pg)

questions.question:
Question 7: A dose of oral 58-Co-labeled cobalamin was administered to a 65-year-old woman. The 
24-hour urinary excretion of radiolabeled cobalamin was found to be < 10%. The test was 
repeated after a 5-day course of antibiotics and showed urinary excretion > 10%. What is 
the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario refers to Schilling's test done for the determination of the cause of B12 
deficiency. Improvement of urinary B12 excretion > 10% after antibiotic administration is 
suggestive of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).

questions.question:
Question 8: A child diagnosed with megaloblastic anemia failed to respond to treatment with vitamin C, 
vitamin B12, and folic acid. He was started on uridine monophosphate which improved his 
symptoms. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Megaloblastic anemia that is responsive to treatment with uridine is suggestive of orotic aciduria. Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. It occurs due to a defect in the 
pyrimidine synthesis pathway causing a failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. It manifests 
in early childhood with anemia and failure to thrive.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 28-year-old woman presents with fatigue and a red, painful tongue. On examination, there 
is reduced vibration sense and proprioception in the feet. She is under treatment for 
Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Peripheral smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented 
neutrophils. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario in a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroiditis is suspicious for 
pernicious anemia. It is an autoimmune cause of B12 deficiency. Antibodies against gastrin are 
not seen in these patients. The following autoantibodies are seen: • Type I or blocking antibodies - prevent the combination of IF and cobalamin • Type II or binding antibodies - prevent attachment of IF to the ileal mucosa • Anti-parietal cell antibodies - target the gastric proton pump located in these cells This leads to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle (IF) and hydrochloric acid produced by 
the parietal cells. The resulting atrophic gastritis causes high gastrin and low pepsinogen 
levels. Lack of IF further causes vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.

questions.question:
Question 10: 1297 
Sold by @itachibot A pathologist receives a gastric biopsy sample of a patient with pernicious anemia. Which of 
the following findings is he unlikely to find?
questions.explanation:
Gastric biopsy in pernicious anemia shows loss of glandular elements, not hypertrophy. This is an autoimmune condition that occurs in genetically susceptible individuals. One of the 
common triggers of the disease process is Helicobacter pylori infection. Gastric biopsy findings in 
pernicious anemia include the following: • Atrophy of all layers of the body and fundus • Loss of glandular elements • Absence of parietal and chief cells and replacement by mucus cells 1304 
Sold by @itachibot • Mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate (excess of CD4 cells against gastric H+/K+-ATPase) • Intestinal metaplasia • Antral mucosa is usually well preserved.

questions.question: Question 11: Patients with pernicious anemia are at a higher risk of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Patients with pernicious anemia have an increased risk of intestinal-type of gastric 
adenocarcinoma and gastric carcinoid tumors. These patients must undergo regular endoscopic 
screening for these conditions. The presumed mechanism is prolonged achlorhydria due to parietal cell loss. This leads to 
hypergastrinemia and cellular hyperplasia.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is the most common cause of folate deficiency?
questions.explanation: Reduced nutritional intake is the most common cause of folate deficiency.

questions.question: Question 13: Dietary folates are absorbed from which of the following sites?
questions.explanation: Dietary folates are absorbed from the duodenum and jejunum in the form of monoglutamates. Vitamin B12 absorption takes place in the terminal ileum.

questions.question:
Question 14: 1298 
Sold by @itachibot A 49-year-old woman is brought with increased forgetfulness and clumsiness for the past 1 
month. Since the death of her husband 3 months ago, she has been tired and eating poorly. 
She began taking over-the-counter iron and folic acid tablets 2 months ago. Examination 
reveals positive Romberg's sign with eyes closed and loss of vibration in lower extremities. 
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of dorsal column involvement of the spinal cord due to 
underlying vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD). It 
affects the following structures: • Dorsal column - sensory loss, paresthesias, incontinence, sensory ataxia (positive Romberg sign 
with eyes closed) • Lateral column - spasticity and paraplegias in later stages Folate deficiency is typically not associated with neurological manifestations. In patients with 
combined deficiency of B12 and folate, B12 deficiency must always be corrected first. This is 
because the administration of folate supplements may improve hematologic abnormalities 
but worsens neurological manifestations. Treatment of cobalamin deficiency is as follows: • Replenishment of body stores: Six 1000-g IM injections of hydroxocobalamin given at 3- to 
7-day intervals. 1305 
Sold by @itachibot • Maintenance therapy: 1000 g hydroxocobalamin IM once every 3 months Treatment of folate deficiency is as follows: • 5–15 mg oral folic acid daily for a minimum of 4 months. Option C: Thiamine deficiency causes Wernicke's syndrome with ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and 
nystagmus. As this is due to cerebellar damage, Romberg's sign would be positive even with eyes 
open. Option D: Pyridoxine deficiency causes pellagra like syndrome with features of dermatitis, 
diarrhea, dementia.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 19-year-old girl with a seizure disorder is started on phenytoin therapy. Which of the 
following must be supplemented in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Usage of phenytoin leads to folate deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. Hence, folic acid must be 
supplemented.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 23-year-old woman comes to you for pre-conceptional counseling. Her previous pregnancy 
resulted in fetal death due to a neural tube defect. What dose of folic acid would you 
recommend?

options.c: 4-5 mg pre-conceptionally and in first trimester

questions.explanation:
The recommended prophylactic dose of folic acid in women who have had a previous fetus with a 
neural tube defect is 4-5 mg daily, pre-conceptionally, and during the first trimester of pregnancy. 
Following the first trimester, these patients are then switched to 400 g of folic acid for the 
remainder of the pregnancy. This high dose of folic acid (4-5 mg) should be initiated at least one to three months before 
pregnancy and should be continued for 12 weeks after pregnancy. The patient can be prescribed 1 
mg tablet of folic acid and advised to take them 4- 5 times a day or they can be recommended 5mg 
tablets/capsules once daily. Prophylactic folic acid with 400 g daily, pre-conceptionally, and throughout pregnancy is 
indicated in all pregnant women to prevent megaloblastic anemia and reduce the incidence of 
neural tube defects.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome (IGS) is an autosomal recessive disorder. IGS occurs due to mutations in either the cubulin (CUBN) or amnionless (AMN) genes. They form 
the cubam receptor responsible for the absorption of the Cbl-IF complex. Hence, this condition 
leads to congenital cobalamin malabsorption. It is the most common cause of megaloblastic 
anemia due to B12 deficiency in infancy in Western countries. Affected children present with lethargy, failure to thrive, and neurological symptoms like 
hypotonia, developmental delay, and movement disorders. Non-specific proteinuria with 
normal renal function is seen in 90% of patients. 1306
